snippet: Across much of the country, sealing or clearing a criminal record after a wrongful conviction is a tangled and expensive process, advocates and former prisoners say.
abstract: Criminal justice advocates and former prisoners nationwide say that sealing or clearing a criminal record after wrongful conviction is tangled and expensive process; it can take years of appeals to courts and pleas to governors to wipe slate clean, and even then, many felony convictions remain on federal databases and pop up during background checks or at traffic stops.
lead_paragraph: Across much of the country, sealing or clearing a criminal record after a wrongful conviction is a tangled and expensive process, advocates and former prisoners say.

headline.seo: Wrongfully Convicted Find Their Record Haunts Them
headline.main: Wrongfully Convicted Often Find Their Record, Unexpunged, Haunts Them
headline.print_headline: Wrongfully Convicted Often Find Their Record, Unexpunged, Haunts Them
